Electrocatalysis is critical in improving the energy conversion efficiency, decreasing carbon emissions, and promoting the development of the green energy industry. A deep understanding of the electrocatalytic processes at nanostructured electrochemical interfaces (electrodes) is required to elucidate the electrocatalytic mechanism and facilitate the rational design of electrocatalysts. Electrocatalytic surfaces, which are structurally and compositionally heterogeneous, are usually analyzed using classical macroscopic electrochemical methods that lack the high spatial resolution and temporal sensitivity required for localized electrochemical measurements. In this regard, advances in electrochemical scanning probe microscopy, including electrochemical scanning tunneling, electrochemical atomic force, scanning electrochemical, and scanning electrochemical cell microscopies, offer significant opportunities to study electrocatalytic phenomena at nanometer and ultimately atomic scales during the reaction process. In this review, we first introduce the basic principles, features, and advantages and disadvantages of each technique of these scanning probe microscopies and outline the key advancements of each technique, particularly in investigating electrocatalysis. Subsequently, hybrid techniques of probe microscopy with synergistic effects are introduced. Then, we summarize the recent progress in the application of in-situ characterization methods in electrocatalysis, including hydrogen evolution/oxidation, oxygen evolution, and CO2 reduction reactions, focusing on the structure-activity correlation, structure evolution/stability, adsorption of the reactants or intermediates, preferred reaction pathways, and selectivity. Finally, the challenges and future developments of in-situ scanning probe microscopy in electrocatalysis are discussed. Graphical Abstract In this review, we describe a systematic framework that clarifies the recent progress in in situ electrochemical scanning probe microscopy (EC-SPMs) techniques for electrocatalytic applications. This study aims to provide nanoscale insights into the local physiochemical properties and structure-activity correlation that allows the electrocatalysis mechanism and rational design of highly efficient electrocatalysts for energy conversion and storage to be explained. Keywords Electrochemical scanning probe microscopies Electrocatalysis Reaction mechanism Structure-activity relationship Interface 1 Introduction Electrocatalysis is vital for clean and efficient energy conversion to address energy crises and environmental contamination. It involves a wide variety of electrochemical transformations occurring at the solid–liquid interface between the electrocatalyst and electrolyte. The key electrocatalytic processes include water splitting for hydrogen production, fuel cells, and nitrogen and carbon fixation [1]. Water splitting involves the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which are sustainable sources of hydrogen energy [2]. Hydrogen-fueled fuel cells can convert chemical energy into electricity via hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [3,4]. Carbon fixation is achieved via the carbon dioxide reduction (CO2RR), which is regarded as a renewable resource to produce value-added chemicals, fuels, and polymers [5]. At the electrochemical interface, the electrocatalytic process usually involves various steps, including electron transfer reactions, adsorption and desorption processes, electrostatic interactions, solvation, and desolvation [6,7], making the reaction mechanism complex to understand. Moreover, the efficiency of the electrocatalytic process highly depends on the nature of the electrochemical interface, which determines the electrochemical transformations between electrical and chemical energies [8]. Thus, a detailed understanding of the electrocatalytic process and structure-activity correlation is crucial in improving the energy efficiency and lowering the manufacturing cost of these electrocatalytic systems. The overall electrocatalytic activity is usually associated with highly localized active sites on heterogeneous electrocatalyst surfaces, that is, energetically distinct surface sites and structural features ranging from the microscale to the atomic scale, which possess the optimal adsorption strength of key reaction intermediates [9–11]. Thus, the analysis of electrocatalytic activity occurring at these surfaces requires high-resolution characterization under reaction conditions. However, classic macroscopic electrochemical measurements [12–14] only provide the averaged information of various interface sites and may “wash out” the key electrochemical characteristics related to the structural heterogeneity, such as defects, grain boundaries, edge sites, and heteroatom doping sites. Although high-resolution microscopies, such as transmission electron [15] and scanning tunneling microscopies [16], can reveal the surface structure and composition of electrocatalysts at the atomic level, they are typically operated under ultrahigh vacuum conditions that usually deviate from the real electrocatalytic reaction conditions. Electrochemical scanning probe microscopy (EC-SPM) techniques [17], including electrochemical scanning tunneling (EC-STM) [18–21], electrochemical atomic force (EC-AFM) [22–25], scanning electrochemical (SECM), and scanning electrochemical cell microscopies (SECCM) [26–30], have significantly contributed to the fundamental understanding of electrocatalysis in recent decades. EC-STM is capable of characterizing the surface structure and electrocatalytic process in an electrochemical environment, benefiting from its instrument design that allows the potential of the tip and sample to be independently adjusted with respect to the reference electrode [31,32]. It has been treated as a promising technique for the operando characterization of electrocatalytic systems with atomic resolution [18,21,33]. EC-AFM [34,35] has been successfully used to study local dynamic surface changes during potential cycling [36] and investigate the surface effect of soluble catalysts [22]. Compared with EC-STM, the preparation of atomically smooth surfaces is not strictly required for EC-AFM studies [37]. EC-STM and EC-AFM are mostly used to characterize surface evolution and adsorption/dissolution information under electrochemical reaction conditions at the nanoscale. SECM [38,39] and SECCM [40,41] are complementary techniques for monitoring local electrochemical reactivity (electrochemical faradaic currents), with the ability to extract more electrochemical information, such as electrochemical fluxes and reaction kinetics. They have been widely used to capture electrochemical imaging or movies down to the nanoscale and have been used to investigate structure-activity relationships for a wide variety of electrocatalysts [13,42–44]. Thus, EC-SPMs methods offer significant opportunities to bridge the gaps between ex-situ examination of electrode surfaces and operando characterization of electrocatalytic systems. Here, we summarize recent developments in the field of electrocatalysis investigated by operando/in-situ EC-SPM (Fig. 1 ). First, the basic working principles of different EC-SPM techniques are introduced, in addition to mentioning their advantages and disadvantages. Second, we discuss the important applications of EC-STM, EC-AFM, SECM, and SECCM in studying the structure-reactivity relationship and electrocatalytic processes of different reactions (e.g., HER/HOR, OER, ORR, and CO2RR). Further, we highlight new insights obtained by these microscopies in understanding the structure-activity correlation and electrocatalytic activity of nanostructure entities. Third, the perspectives and outlook of the EC-SPMs methods applied in electrocatalysis are discussed. 2 Electrochemical scanning probe microscopy Scanning probe microscopy (SPM) is primarily divided into two categories: scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM). Their applications in electrochemistry have probed the local structural properties at the electrified solid-liquid interface [45]. At the dawn of using STM to study the electrode structure, the sample has to be removed from the solution and checked in ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) conditions, which is known as ‘ex-situ’ method [46]. In 1986, the first example of using STM to characterize a sample immersed in a liquid with atomic resolution was demonstrated by Sonnenfeld et al. [47]. Thereafter, in-situ STM characterization was realized by Bard et al. [48] under solution conditions with a relatively low spatial resolution of 30 nm. In 1988, Itaya et al. [49] proposed a four-electrode setup for STM, in which the potentials of the tip and the sample referred to the reference electrode could be independently controlled. This is the first formal EC-STM study to monitor the dynamic deposition and dissolution of Ag on electrode surfaces under potentiostatic conditions. Since AFM was first developed by Gerber [50], it has not only contributed to the measurements of conductive but also non-conductive surfaces in aqueous solutions at the atomic scale [51]. In 1991, the dynamic morphology of the gold surface in acidic media during the electrochemical oxidation process was investigated with potential control using in-situ AFM, enabling the first EC-AFM study [34]. Compared with EC-STM and EC-AFM probes, scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) and scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM) techniques can resolve the electrochemical reactivity at the nanoscale, becoming emerging research directions for EC-SPMs. With the introduction of ultramicroelectrodes (UMEs) [52], the idea of employing small and mobile tips to perform electrochemical measurements was attempted by several groups [53–55]. In 1989, Bard et al. [56] invented the SECM technique and employed collection and feedback modes for scanning. As a new type of scanning electrochemical probe microscopy, SECCM is a technique based on a theta pipette to measure the topography and local functional properties of interfaces [40,41]. This technique is amenable to high mass transfer rates and devoid of impregnation, which does not require the entire sample to be immersed in the electrolyte solution [57]. These advancements enable EC-SPMs to be versatile experimental tools for investigating electrocatalytic solid-liquid interfaces in-situ with nanoscale resolution. A comparison of EC-SPMs discussed in this review and their hybrid techniques is presented in Table 1 . 2.1 Electrochemical scanning tunneling microscopy EC-STM is an extended technique based on conventional STM working under UHV conditions, which can operate in electrolyte solutions [49,58]. The tunneling current between the metallic tip and sample surface was used to obtain information about the topography and electronic structure of the surface. A four-electrode electrochemical bipotentiostat that can independently control the potentials of the sample (E S) and STM tip (E T) with respect to a reference electrode (RE) was implemented using the STM setup. Thus, potentiodynamic images can be recorded. (Fig. 2 ) [49,58,59]. The electrochemical current (i S) flowing through the sample and counter electrode (CE) can be detected using a current follower. A bias voltage (E b) was applied between the sample (WE1) and tip (WE2), which was determined by the potential difference (E b = E T – E S). Under the reaction conditions, a faradaic current at the STM tip is superimposed on a tunneling current (i T) (a non-faradaic current), which passes an operational amplifier before entering the feedback loop of the STM. To suppress the disruptive faradaic current at the tip, the most commonly used methods involve insulating a major part of the tip by coating it with glass, [60] polymers [61], or inorganic oxides [62]. Thus, the faradaic current can decrease to an extent that is much smaller than the tunneling current (0.1–10 nA) by reducing the tip area exposed to the electrolyte solution. E T must be chosen carefully to minimize the Faradaic current through the tip, which could disturb the tip height control [59]. Furthermore, E T is restricted to a potential region dictated by the electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte or the stability of the tip material (e.g., tip oxidation) [63]. Note that the diffusion of electrochemical reactants to the imaged area is limited to some extent because of the close tip-to-sample separation, which distorts the applied potential value with increasing IR drops. Consequently, kinetic data derived from EC-STM must be obtained carefully, as the presence of the tip can affect the kinetics of the electrochemical reactions [64]. The tunneling process through an electrolyte is more complex than that in vacuum because of the presence of the solution species in the tip-sample gap. The tunneling current of EC-STM in the electrolyte did not depend exponentially on the tip-sample distance, as observed in UHV. Instead, modulation of the tunneling current as a function of the tip-surface distance was detected by high-resolution in-situ distance tunneling spectroscopy (DST) [65,66]. Moreover, the tunneling barriers in the electrochemical environment are significantly lower than those in UHV [67,68]. This can be rationalized by water adsorption on the electrode surface, which usually decreases the work functions of the metal surfaces [68]. EC-STM is commonly operated in the constant current mode. E b is fixed at a constant value, and E T and E S can be simultaneously changed. The scanning tip was brought to a distance where the wave functions of the tip and sample surface started to overlap, and electron tunneling occurred in the electrolyte. The vertical distance (z) between the tip and sample was dynamically adjusted using the feedback loop to retain a constant i T at each lateral point (x,y) of the sample. Constant-height mode scanning can be operated by switching off the feedback system while keeping z constant with the recording current i T of each (x,y) point to reflect the surface height variations. This mode is limited to flat sample surfaces because high surface protrusions can easily crash the tip. In return, the constant height mode enables a high scan rate, which can improve the time resolution of imaging acquisition. EC-STM is critical in the in-situ investigation of electrocatalysis. This can provide surface structure information for electrocatalysts [69] and characterize the electrocatalytic process [70]. EC-STM studies of electrocatalysis began with fundamental work on single-crystal metals [68,63,64,71,72] and metal alloy electrodes [73,74]. With further development of EC-STM, a deeper understanding of the electrocatalytic processes associated with reactant adsorption/desorption [75,76] and surface transformation [20,77,78] can be obtained. Recently, a trend to combine in-situ EC-STM studies with other techniques has occurred, including inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) [79], electrochemical tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) [80], and differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy (DEMS) [81], to correlate the structural properties with their reactivity. Advances in computing capacity and microprocessor technology have enabled the detection of highly dynamic electrocatalytic processes in the electrochemical environment. Magnussen et al. [82] built an electrochemical video-STM (high-speed EC-STM), which allows obtaining atomic resolution images with high time resolution ≤ 100 ms. This technique has been employed to observe the dissolution and electrodeposition of Cu(100) in a diluted HCl solution [83] to quantitatively study adsorbate diffusion at solid-liquid interfaces, such as sulfide adsorbate motion on Cu(100) in an HCl solution [84], and monitor nanoscale surface dynamics on gold electrode surfaces [85,86]. These direct observations of dynamic electrochemical processes in “real time” enabled by electrochemical video-STM are fundamentally important to interpret mechanisms of electrocatalytic reactions and surface growth processes. For instance, the surface reconstruction of Cu(100) electrodes in a perchloric acid solution induced by hydrogen evolution was revealed by electrochemical video-STM [87]. The formation of strip-like structure that parallels to the Cu lattice was detected within less than 0.1 s when the electrode potential was decreased to the hydrogen evolution region. Correlative electrochemical measurements revealed an increased HER rate with this surface structure, providing a significant atomic-scale understanding of the electrocatalytic reaction. In addition to improving the time resolution, as stated above, scanning noise microscopy (SNM) [88,89] was developed to measure the noise parameters as a function of the tunneling current, generating noise images with Ångstrom spatial resolution. Based on this idea, Pfisterer et al. [21] investigated active sites at the nanoscale under reaction conditions. Local electrocatalytic processes cause variations in the local evolution of hydrogen gas, which can randomly modify the tunneling barrier. Consequently, the tunneling current noise changes to reflect the distribution of the active sites. Note that the resolution herein is limited to 1–2 nm, which does not yet reach the ultimate goal of resolving the catalytic surface in-situ with atomic resolution. The reason might be that the diffusion of the products from the active sites creates the area in which the noise is larger than the true active sites [90]. 2.2 Electrochemical atomic force microscopy In contrast to EC-STM, EC-AFM no longer uses electron tunneling to probe the local properties of the sample surface, but rather the tip-sample force interactions, which can be applied to a wider variety of materials, including insulators. Manne et al. [91] began the initial in-situ AFM work to examine the electrochemical processes of metal electrode surfaces. In an EC-AFM system, as shown in Fig. 3 , an external potentiostat is required to provide potential control for general electrochemical measurements, and the sample electrode is submerged in a fluid cell with a typical three-electrode setup. A sharp EC-AFM tip was located at the end of the cantilever to detect mechanical interactions between the tip and sample surface, which led to cantilever deflection, and scan across the sample surface driven by a piezo scanner in a fluid electrolyte. A feedback loop system consisting of a laser and position-sensitive photodiode was used to monitor the cantilever deflection and regulate the distance between the tip and sample. The motion of the tip in the z direction as a function of the lateral location (x,y) was recorded by measuring the laser deflection signal, resulting in a three-dimensional topography of the sample surface. EC-AFM can be operated in two basic modes: contact and non-contact [92,93]. In the contact mode, the tip is dragged across the sample surface and brought into the repulsive force regime. An electronic feedback loop maintains a constant normal force by adjusting the distance between the sample and tip. Owing to direct contact, mechanical destruction and deformation of the tip and sample may occur. These potential risks of sample or tip damage in the contact mode can be avoided by the tapping mode. In this mode, the cantilever oscillated above the sample surface at resonance. The presence of attractive and repulsive force components in the interaction force and their nonlinear character determines the amplitude oscillation, and the amplitude commonly serves as a control parameter to measure the topography of the sample surface. Although EC-AFM usually exhibits a relatively lower lateral resolution than EC-STM, its capability and application scope can be extended by integrating it with new measurement methods such as frequency modulation, potential-sensing measurement, and mechanical cyclic voltammetry (mCV) curves. This allows EC-AFM to measure the physical and chemical properties of a wide range of electrochemical materials, including semiconductors and soft electrode materials, under reaction conditions, which is normally difficult in EC-STM measurements. Fukuma et al. [94] initially presented the first frequency modulation (FM) AFM working in liquid. The hexagonal lattice of the (001) surface and the defects of muscovite mica were resolved with vertical and lateral resolutions of 2–6 and 300 pm, respectively. In this FM-AFM, the cantilever oscillates at its resonance frequency. The interaction force between the tip and sample induces a frequency shift of the cantilever, which can be detected by an FM demodulator. FM-AFM has high sensitivity to the force in liquids, enabling EC-FM-AFM to become another promising tool for characterizing solid-liquid interfaces at the atomic level [95]. EC-AFM is a highly demanded approach for studying local electrochemistry. Boettcher and co-workers have developed a potential-sensing EC-AFM (PS-EC-AFM) method to measure the surface potential of heterogeneous (photo) electrochemical systems in-situ [96]. A fully electrically insulated tip, except for the exposed conducting tip with a nanometer radius, was kept in direct contact with the substrate catalyst of interest using force feedback to control the tip-substrate interactions. The Fermi levels of the substrate and the tip were assumed to be in equilibrium. Thus, it was possible to directly probe the substrate surface potential using the tip potential. To demonstrate its utility, they measured the potential- and thickness-dependent electronic properties of a cobalt (oxy) hydroxide phosphate (CoPi) catalyst deposited on hematite (α-Fe2O3) photoelectrodes, which act as both a hole collector and OER catalyst. Moreover, the concept of mechanical cyclic voltammetry (mCV) curves of in-situ EC-AFM was developed to understand the heterogeneity of electrochemical processes at the nanoscale [97]. Electrochemical-mechanical coupling behavior was detected, showing the correlation between the electrochemical current and local strain signal during the proton insertion/deinsertion processes at anhydrous and hydrated WO3 electrodes. The mCV mapping methodology can be used to resolve heterogeneous electrochemical insertion across the electrode without interference from cell resistance or unwanted side reactions. 2.3 Scanning electrochemical microscopy SECM employs an ultramicroelectrode (UME) tip (typically ≤ 25 µm) to move above a substrate of interest immersed in the solution at a certain distance (tens of nanometers to 10 µm) using piezo controllers [56,98,99]. The UME performs as a working electrode in a cell that is completed by counter and reference electrodes, and a substrate can be connected to a bipotentiostat as a second working electrode. The electrochemical reactions at the tip, substrate, or both can be detected. Despite the geometric similarity between EC-STM and SECM, the operating principles of the tip-substrate interaction are different. First, EC-STM depends on the flow of a tunneling current, but SECM utilizes the faradaic current that is induced by redox-active processes at the tip and the substrate [56]. Second, the positional feedback of EC-STM relies on a tunneling current between the tip and the sample, so the z-distance is limited to the order of 1 nm or less. SECM can probe the diffusion layer on the electrode, but its large working distance and tip size limit its achievable resolution [98]. Finally, the tunneling current of EC-STM is desirable for imaging. The local electrochemistry can be reflected by EC-STM only if it is accompanied by sharp contrast changes in topography induced by adsorption, deposition, and dissolution processes. However, the tip current of SECM is controlled by the mass transfer in the solution and the electron transfer kinetics at the tip and sample, which allows the monitoring of local electrochemical heterogeneity [99], detection of adsorbed intermediates [100,101], and imaging the local reaction rate of the products of interest [26,102]. As shown in Fig. 4 , the SECM scanning mode can be divided into several categories, including the feedback, tip generation/substrate collection, substrate generation/tip collection, and redox competition modes. In the feedback scanning mode [103], a redox mediator (e.g., a reduced species, R) in the solution is oxidized at the tip by applying a positive potential. When the tip approaches a certain distance close to the conducting substrate, the generated flux (an oxidized species, O) can diffuse and be reduced back to R (Fig. 4(b)). Consequently, an additional R flux to the tip can be produced, generating “positive feedback”. If an insulator substrate is involved in this process (Fig. 4(c)), it blocks the diffusion of R generated at the tip when the tip is brought close to the inert substrate, which is defined as “negative feedback”. The feedback mode has been widely employed to investigate electron transfer kinetics [104,105]. In the tip generation/substrate collection (TG/SC) (Fig. 4(d)) and substrate generation/tip collection (SG/TC) modes (Fig. 4(e)), electrochemically active species can be produced at the tip or substrate and subsequently detected at the substrate or tip. Compared with the feedback mode, the tip/sample separation distance of these two modes is not necessarily very small, facilitating imaging with nanoelectrodes. The TG/SC mode was developed very early [106] and is more sensitive than the SG/TC mode. The TG/SC mode is widely used for investigating reaction kinetics and screening electrocatalysts (e.g., oxygen reduction reaction). The tip of the SG/TC mode can probe the reactions occurring at the substrate. Thus, the “active sites” on the substrate with higher reaction rates can be identified. This mode was employed to measure the concentration profiles and chemical fluxes of the substrate [107]. In the redox competitive mode (Fig. 4(f)), the tip current drops when the UME probe approaches the substrate because the tip and substrate compete for the same species. This mode is identical to the shielding mode of SECM, which was introduced using a (photo)electrocatalytic process a few years earlier [108]. The mode can obtain high-resolution imaging of the local catalytic activity because the contribution of the background current to the analytical signal is not as large as that of the TG/SC and SG/TC modes [109]. The scanning resolution can be further improved by decreasing the size of the SECM tip. SECM has recently been employed to characterize gas-involved electrocatalytic reactions [102,110–112] because of its advantages over conventional stationary and rotating disk (ring) electrodes. First, the high resolution (up to submicron) enables SECM to identify the electrochemical heterogeneity over nanoscale systems. Second, a higher mass transfer derived from hemispherical diffusion around the UME can be achieved, which forms a steady-state current and promotes better sensitivity. Third, the lower current generated on the UME of the SECM reduces electrode blockage and inaccurate current measurements caused by bubble formation. However, SECM faces the challenge that electrochemical activity and topography are not easily separated, which is problematic for nanoscale imaging. To solve this issue, much effort has been devoted to integrating SECM with other SPM techniques such as AFM [113,114], STM [115,116], scanning ion conductance microscopy (SICM) [116–119], and SECCM [120], to obtain precise positional feedback, as described vide infra. 2.4 Scanning electrochemical cell microscopy In 2009, the scanning micropipette contact method (SMCM) with a single-barrel pipette (diameter of 300 nm to 1 μm), also known as the single-barrel SECCM, was invented to address electrode activity [121]. The SECCM based on a mobile micro- or nanopipette double-barrel cell (double-barrel SECCM) was developed in 2010 [41]. Recently, single-barrel SECCM with a much smaller nanopipette size compared with SMCM has been used to address new areas in high-resolution (down to 30 nm) electrochemistry [122], including the microstructural origin of electrocatalytic CO2 electroreduction on a polycrystalline Au electrode [123], potential-current relationship of steps and edges on the 2D material surface [124,125], and electrochemical properties across a single entity (nanoparticles) [122,126]. SECCM has some advantages over the traditional SECM. First, SECCM allows both the electrochemical activity and topography of the surface, even with high roughness up to several µm [127], to be mapped, but SECM is usually operated in a constant plane scanning mode with no feedback position. Second, SECCM enables the direct monitoring of electrochemical activity by making a droplet contact with the substrate. In contrast, SECM probes indirect substrate activity, which connects spatially dependent fluxes of reactants, products, and intermediates from the substrate at the tip. Third, the SECCM method uses the meniscus at the end of the micro- or nanopipette to land on a surface with only a small confined area. The entire sample is not required to be immersed in the electrolyte solution during the experiment time (up to hours), as demanded by the SECM, which may cause deterioration of the sample. SECCM uses a tiny meniscus at the end of a single- or double-barrel pipette for the simultaneous mapping of surface topography and electrochemical activities. Thus far, the operation process consists of two steps: meniscus landing control and electrochemical characterization. The schematic setups of the double- and single-barrel SECCM are illustrated in Fig. 5 . For the double-barrel SECCM, a glass theta pipette was filled with the electrolyte solution and contained a quasi-reference counter electrode (QRCE) in each barrel (Fig. 5(a)). The pipette was mounted on a piezoelectric positioner, which allowed it to move in all the three dimensions. Precise control of pipette landing relies on a feedback loop of ion conductance current (i DC) across the liquid meniscus formed at the end of the pipette, generated by applying a potential bias, V 2, between the two QRCEs. The z position of the pipette (normal to the sample surface) is sinusoidally modulated by a lock-in amplifier, generating an alternating current component of the i DC at the same frequency (i AC). i AC is negligible when the pipette is in air, while it will reach a measurable amplitude once contact between the meniscus and surface is established. A threshold value of i AC magnitude was set to control the distance between the meniscus and sample surface. In a typical electrochemical measurement, the V 1 potential was applied to one of the QRCEs. The substrate potential, E s, can be adjusted by changing V 1 while V 2 is fixed, which equals –(V 1+1/2V 2). The resulting current flowing through the sample is denoted as i surf. For single-barrel SECCM (Fig. 5(b)), a QRCE was inserted into a single-barrel pipette filled with the electrolyte. A voltage V 1 was applied to the QRCE to drive the reaction of interest, and the sample (working electrode) was grounded. The current i surf is used as the feedback signal during the landing process to control the position of the meniscus z. This feedback technique limits the single-barrel SECCM to conductive materials, whereas that of the double-barrel SECCM is applicable to both conductive and semi conductive materials. Nevertheless, the small radius of the meniscus in the single-barrel setup leads to a higher lateral resolution, even down to the nanometer scale, which is hardly possible in a double-barrel setup. The most commonly used scanning modes of the SECCM include the continuous scanning [128] (constant-height mode) and hopping scanning modes [129]. Continuous scanning is typically used in the double-barrel SECCM. Once the meniscus contacts the sample surface, the SECCM probe can scan over the surface at a constant velocity, and the tip-to-sample separation of the probe can be adjusted at set time intervals (typically on a millisecond scale) to maintain a defined constant i AC. In this manner, high-resolution images of local electrochemical activity and topography can be simultaneously obtained. The hopping scanning mode can be applied to both single-barrel and double-barrel SECCM. The probe approaches the surface and makes the meniscus contact with the surface using a threshold value (i surf or i AC). Electrochemical measurement methods, such as CV or LSV, were then applied. The probe was quickly retracted to break the meniscus and move to the next landing position. By repeating the entire process, the electrochemical activity maps were constructed from a series of parallel line scans. Compared with other high-resolution microscopy techniques, such as Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), SECCM has significantly contributed to the understanding of the correlative structure-activity relationship of electrocatalytic reactions [13,123,130]. For instance, the combination of SECCM and EBSD has been demonstrated as a means of studying electrochemistry and electrocatalysis at individual grains of polycrystalline electrodes [131,132]. A recent co-located SECCM and EBSD study worked as a pseudo-single screening approach to reveal the structure-activity correlation for CO2RR on a polycrystalline Cu surface [133]. For low-index facets, an activity trend of (111) < (100) < (110) was observed under CO2RR conditions. For high-index facets, the CO2RR activity was higher, especially more prominent with a high density of steps and types. Electrochemical stripping of the passive layer on the Cu surface was achieved for each pixel in the SECCM scans. The relative ease of stripping follows the order of (100) > (111) > (110), which is highly grain-dependent. A considerable number of spatial-resolved linear sweep voltammograms (up to 2500) over 60 different grains in a single map were obtained using SECCM. These electrocatalytic data can be correlated with the crystallographic orientations characterized by EBSD, enabling selectivity measurements for CO2RR studies. 2.5 Hybrid techniques of electrochemical scanning probe microscopies EC-STM and EC-AFM offer significant opportunities to investigate surface processes during electrochemical reactions at the nanoscale level. The Faradaic currents arising from electrochemical reactions cannot be directly measured because of their principles of imaging (vide supra), making them unable to detect local electrochemical activities. In contrast, the SECM technique can record steady-state current without significant convection effect, allowing the distinction of electrochemical activities between different nano-subjects. The SECM current recorded as a function of the tip position depends on both the surface topography and electrochemical activity; however, SECM has no positional feedback with the conventional constant plane scanning mode. Therefore, hybrid techniques with dual probes such as SECM-AFM [113,114,134], SECM-STM [115,116], SECM-SICM [117–119,135], and SECM-SECCM [120] have been successfully developed for simultaneously acquiring topography and electrochemical maps. These hybrid techniques have potential applications in corrosion, energy-related materials, and biological systems [115,136]. 2.5.1 SECM-AFM A combined SECM-AFM in contact mode was developed by Macpherson et al. [113], allowing for the first simultaneous topographical and electrochemical measurements with high spatial resolution. The scanning probe of SECM-AFM consists of flattened and etched Pt wires coated with insulating epoxy resin; only the end of the etched Pt is exposed to the solution. The flattened part served as a force sensor and the etched part was used as an electrode. To avoid a probable short circuit in this mode when conductive substrates are imaged, a lift mode was developed with two scans across the surface [137]. In this mode, topography scans first, and electrochemical scanning follows along the same lines as in the first scan. The tapping mode of SECM-AFM imposes an oscillation on the cantilever at or near the resonance frequency, which can minimize the frictional forces at the sample surface. This mode is particularly useful for imaging biological species [138]. The fabrication of dual-functional SECM-AFM probes remains a major challenge in achieving reliable and high-resolution imaging. Two complicated aspects of the fabrication process are involved. First, a nanoelectrode with a well-defined electroactive area has to be made, located at the apex of the AFM tip [113,139–141] or at some distance from the nonconductive tip apex [114,142,143]. Second, current leakage must be avoided by properly insulating the electrically conducting part of the fabricated electrode. Therefore, batch microfabrication of SECM-AFM probes with good reliability, durability, and low cost is in high demand for the further development of SECM-AFM. Another challenge is the theoretical consideration of predicting the SECM-AFM current response. Only a few related studies have used the finite element method (FEM) and boundary element method (BEM) [144–146], which may be due to the more complex geometry of the SECM-AFM probe compared to that of the SECM probe. 2.5.2 SECM-STM To assess the electrochemical properties of the nanosized structure, EC-STM was coupled with SECM by the Wittstock group to obtain a topography and electrochemical activity map of a rough surface [116]. Two separated scans were obtained. First, the spatial topography was acquired using an EC-STM scan. The EC-STM data were then used to guide the probe at a larger distance parallel to the surface, conducting an SECM scan at a gold electrode after changing the probe potential to oxidize the mediator. This allows correlated topography at a surface whose roughness is much larger than the UME-surface distance to be achieved, and a significant improvement in lateral resolution compared to conventional SECM is obtained. Reports on SECM-STM applications are limited and primarily focus on the acquisition of asynchronous topography and electrochemical activity in separated scans. More recently, synchronous topographical and electrochemical maps in one scan were achieved using scanning electrochemical probe microscopy with a “tip hopping-potential pulse” imaging protocol [147]. The tip was biased at a constant potential where no faradaic current was observed in the bulk solution. The tip approached towards the sample surface until a predefined tunneling and/or contact current was detected. Then, the potential of the sample was changed to a value that could drive a faradaic reaction, and the generated products were monitored at the tip. Subsequently, the sample potential was swept back to a value that was not large enough to drive an electrochemical reaction, and the tip was retracted away from the sample surface and moved to the next point. The entire process is repeated at a series of points. In this study, this strategy was employed to characterize the HER activity of 2D Au nanocrystals. However, the imaging resolution of this work needs to be further improved using an STM positioning system in the future. 2.5.3 SECM-SICM Compared to SECM, scanning ion conductance microscopy (SICM) uses a much simpler type of probe and can obtain a noncontact topography with nanometer-scale resolution. The SICM was first invented by Hansma et al. [148] to obtain high-resolution and ion-current images of nonconducting surfaces in an electrolytic solution. In the SICM setup, a bias is applied between a quasi-reference counter electrode (QRCE) in an electrolyte-filled nanopipette and a second QRCE that resides in the bulk solution to generate an ion current. When the nanopipette was far from the sample surface, the ion current reached its maximum value. As the nanopipette approaches the surface to a distance similar to the diameter of the nanopipette, the ion current undergoes a rapid drop because the sample impedes ion flow. The ion current is highly sensitive to tip-to-sample separation, and three basic scanning modes have been developed: non-modulated [148], modulated [149–151], and hopping modes [152–154]. Significant advances have been witnessed in instrumentation [155,156], scan protocols [117,155,157], and algorithm improvements [158,159] to reduce the scan time and achieve higher resolution. In addition to topographic imaging, SICM is emerging as a multifunctional tool and a variety of physicochemical properties can be elucidated [160–165]. For example, SICM has demonstrated the potential for mapping (electro)chemical reactions, including catalysis, as a change in ion conductance is observed inside the nanopipette when it approaches an active site [166]. Moreover, SICM with a fine nanopipette was used to examine the electrocatalytic oxidation activity of borohydride in ensembles of AuNPs on a carbon support with high resolution and precision (30 nm resolution, 2600 pixels µm−2) by employing a self-referencing hopping mode protocol [167]. Bias-modulated (BM)-SICM, introduced by Unwin and coworkers [151], has demonstrated the ability to separate nanoscale charge mapping from topography by sensing the local ionic atmosphere within a double layer [168], which has been applied in both biomimetic/materials and living cells [169–171]. The SICM is able to characterize the topography during the reaction process, but it is not chemically sensitive enough to unravel local electrochemical reactivity. To circumvent this limitation, Hersam and co-workers developed a hybrid of SICM with SECM for the simultaneous electrochemical imaging of a gold film on a glass substrate and topography with submicrometer resolution [172]. They fabricated a dual-functional probe by coating a conductive gold film on one side of a single-barrel nanopipette, followed by the deposition of an insulating Al2O3 layer. The end of the nanopipette was milled using a focused ion beam (FIB) to expose the gold film as an electrode. A similar strategy of probe fabrication has been used for SECM-SICM to image enzymes and living cells and to study the permeation properties of electroactive species through the cellular membrane [173]. Another quick and simple probe fabrication method for SECM-SICM was developed by Korchev and co-workers [135]. One barrel of a double-barrel pipette was filled with the electrolyte for SICM, and the other barrel was filled with carbon to be used as the SECM nanoelectrode. The carbon electrode was made by flowing butane gas through only one barrel to deposit carbon, while the other barrel remained blocked. The probe fabrication was controllable with a pipette radius ranging from 10 nm to 1 µm. Carbon electrodes have shown advantages in SECM-SICM studies in life sciences [119,135] and electrocatalysts [119]. With further probe modification, such as electrodeposition of iridium oxide [174] and electropolymerization of polyaniline [175] onto nanoelectrodes used for SECM, SECM-SICM can simultaneously control the probe position and measure local pH with high spatial resolution. Moreover, the local pH detection of single living cancer cells was recently realized by self-assembling a dual-barrel nanoprobe with a zwitterion-like membrane, which possesses a sensitivity > 0.01 units, 2 ms response time, and 50 nm spatial resolution [176]. 2.5.4 SECM-SECCM The SECCM technique has high control over the meniscus contact on a surface. Thus, coupling SECM with SECCM allows both electrochemical activity and topography to be mapped. A quad-barrel probe used for SECM-SECCM [120] was fabricated by depositing carbon into two diagonally opposite barrels of a laser-pulled quad-barrel pipet, with the other two barrels filled with the electrolyte. These two carbon electrodes can be used to drive electrochemical reactions. A bias was applied to two quasi-reference counter electrodes (QRCEs) to drive the ion conductance current. This technique combines the merits of SECM and SECCM and has demonstrated its abilities in a wide range of applications, including examining the electrochemical activity of electrodes (individual single-walled carbon nanotubes and gold band electrodes) and investigating a redox reaction at an insulating surface. 3 Applications in gas-involved electrocatalysis The capability of electrochemical scanning probe microscopies (EC-SPMs) to investigate their electrocatalytic activities has been exploited and summarized by several groups [13,21,75,102,123,177–180], demonstrating rapid development in the field of electrocatalysis. In this section, we focus on their recent applications in gas-involved electrocatalysis, including the HER/HOR, OER, ORR, and CO2RR. HER/HOR is a typical two-electron reaction, and the adsorbed intermediates, for example, absorbed hydrogen, are relatively simple. Most research has focused on investigating structure-activity correlations. In OER studies, it is easier for surface catalysts to undergo structural reconstruction/dissolution because of the high overpotential for oxidation. In-situ EC-SPMs characterizations have been conducted to monitor this degradation process at the nanoscale. Molecular catalysts such as metal-based phthalocyanine (MPc) for the ORR are important models that can be revealed by EC-STM. Electrocatalytic behavior has recently become a popular topic. The formation mechanism of polycarbon products in the CO2RR is highly complex, involving multiple electron and proton transfer steps. In-situ EC-SPMs and correlative multi-microscopic characterizations of CO2RR catalysts are crucial in demonstrating reaction pathways and selectivity. The key factors affecting electrocatalytic activities and mechanism interpretation of these reactions are discussed, followed by current examples of investigations of structure-activity correlation and electrocatalytic processes using in-situ/operando EC-SPMs. 3.1 HER/HOR HER, as the cathodic reaction of water splitting, has attracted significant attention because it is a feasible approach to produce clean hydrogen energy [2]. The first step of the HER involves hydrogen adsorption on the active site of the catalyst surface by the reduction of a proton from the acid solution (Volmer step). The second step is the formation of molecular H2, either through a second adsorbed hydrogen atom (H*) combined with an electron and a proton (Heyrovsky step) or through a recombination of two H* (Tafel step). A volcano plot was constructed by comparing the hydrogen binding energy (HBE) of the metal with the exchange current density [181], suggesting that the HBE of an ideal HER electrocatalyst should not be too strong or too weak. The adsorption free energy of H* (ΔG H*) was calculated for various metallic surfaces and a similar volcano shape was obtained, confirming that HBE can be used as a descriptor for the HER [182]. The HBE model has been employed for the discovery of new catalysts, such as MoS2, and has helped explain the nature of the active sites facilitating high HER activities [183,184]. In an alkaline electrolyte, this reaction requires additional water dissociation to generate protons that increase the energy barrier, making the kinetics of the alkaline HER more sluggish than in an acidic solution [185,186]. It has been reported that the HER kinetics of Pt(111) in alkaline solutions are significantly enhanced by the incorporation of Ni(OH)2 clusters. In a bifunctional mechanism, the edges of the Ni(OH)2 clusters promote water dissociation and the nearby Pt surfaces facilitate H adsorption [187]. Furthermore, the activity trends in the Pt(111) decorated with 3d-Metal (Ni, Co, Fe, Mn) hydr(oxy)oxides for HER were investigated [188], indicating a balance between promoting water dissociation and maintaining a moderate oxophilic group affinity with OHad, together with an optimal Pt-Had, playing an important role in the HER kinetics. HOR in acidic media follows the following pathway: (1) dissociative adsorption of hydrogen without electron transfer (Tafel), (2) dissociative ionization of H2 (Heyrovsky), and (3) oxidative desorption of adsorbed H* (Volmer). Tailored ΔG H* contributed to enhanced HOR activity in acid for numerous electrocatalysts, such as Ru@Pt core-shell nanoparticles[189] and TiWC cores decorated with Pt surface coatings [190]. The alkaline HOR activity was found to be several orders of magnitude lower than that in acidic medium [191–193]. The pathway of the HOR in alkaline solutions is controversial [194–197]. The Heyrovsky step can be written as in Eq. (1): (1) H2 + OH− + * → H* + H2O + e− OH− is argued to be adsorbed OH (OH*) via Eq. (2): (2) OH− + * → OH* + e− Then, the Heyrovsky step (Eq. (1)) can be expressed by Eq. (3). (3) H2 + OH* → H* + H2O The co-adsorption of hydrogen and hydroxy species is required on the catalyst surface. For instance, Ru atoms act as more oxophilic sites to facilitate the adsorption of OHad, which then reacts with the Had adsorbed on the Pt surface. Ir can accommodate both the OHad and Had species. Thus, the HOR activities in the base were considerably improved by the promotion of hydroxyl adsorption on PtRu and Ir [198]. However, the HBE theory proposes that optimizing HBE so that Had is the key to boosting alkaline HOR kinetics. Yan et al. [196] reported a correlation between HBE and HOR activity on polycrystalline Pt at different pH values. The HOR activity decreased with increasing pH, while the HBE increased with pH, indicating that an excessively strong HBE inhibits the HOR. The HER/HOR mechanisms are not yet fully understood. EC-SPMs can be employed to reveal structure-activity correlations and characterize the electrocatalytic process, which will significantly advance the understanding of the mechanism. To interpret the HER/HOR mechanism in detail, combinations of in-situ X-ray microscopy, infrared spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and theoretical calculations are required [130,194]. 3.1.1 Revealing structure-activity correlation EC-SPMs provide a much deeper understanding of structural control (e.g., steps, grain boundary, crystalline orientation, and defects) in electrocatalysis. Recently, EC-STM was used to explore the structure of HER/HOR electrocatalysts and its effect towards HER/HOR activity. For instance, a higher tunneling current noise was detected at the step defects of Pt(111) than at the terrace defects under HER conditions (Figs. 6(a)–(c) ) [21]. The HER activity of Pd islands on a Au(111) substrate was also investigated, where the largest noise level of the tunneling current was observed for a few Pd atoms that were close to the boundary (Figs. 6(d)–(f)). This method can identify the distribution of active sites by monitoring the tunneling current noise level of EC-STM [21]. 2D nanomaterials such as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) and metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes) have attracted increasing interest owing to their low cost, high specific surface area, and tunable electronic properties [199]. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has been proposed as a promising HER catalyst because its hydrogen adsorption energy is similar to that of platinum [183]. Several efforts have been made to enhance the catalytic performance of MoS2 [200–204]. The structure controls the electrocatalytic processes of 2D transition metal dichalcogenides (e.g., MoX 2, X = Se, S), which were also visualized using the EC-STM method [21] reported by Pfisterer et al. under HER conditions. The edges of MoS2 and MoSe2 flakes showed enhanced HER activities with additional “noise” features, but the basal plane surface remained inactive [205]. When additional point defects, including Mo and S vacancies, were introduced into the basal planes using a helium ion microscope (HIM), the HER activity of the MoS2 basal plane was activated even at low overpotentials. At higher overpotentials, the contribution from the edges dominated the HER activity compared to that of the basal plane. The SECM technique can provide a simple method for extracting kinetic information from 2D materials. Structural engineering strategies, such as creating Mo or S vacancies [201], introducing strains [206,207], and doping with heteroatoms [203,204], have been devoted to improving the HER activity of the basal plane of MoS2. A detailed kinetic study of the HER on strained MoS2 with S vacancies was conducted using the SG/TC SECM [26]. The HER electron transfer (ET) kinetics of the unstrained and strained S vacancies on the basal planes of the MoS2 monolayer were compared. The ET rate constant of strained S vacancies (formal potential E 0 = –0.53 V vs. Ag/AgCl, electron-transfer coefficient α = 0.4, k 0 = 1.0 × 10−3 cm s−1) is 4 times higher than that of unstrained S vacancies (E 0 = –0.53 V Ag/AgCl, α = 0.4, k 0 = 2.3 × 10−4 cm s−1). Similarly, the HER electrocatalytic activities on the basal plane of MXenes, a new family of 2D materials, were manipulated by preparing mixed MXenes with a high secondary metal content (M-Ti4N3T x , M = V, Cr, Mo, or Mn, T x = O and/or OH) [208]. The HER activities of M-Ti4N3T x MXenes were in the order of V-Ti4N3T x > Cr-Ti4N3T x > Mo-Ti4N3T x > Mn-Ti4N3T x > pristine Ti4N3T x (overpotential as low as –330 mV at –10 mA cm−2). SECM studies revealed that the basal plane of single M-Ti4N3T x nanoflakes exhibited strong HER activity because of the large number of exposed metallic sites for proton adsorption, providing experimental evidence for basal plane catalytic activity, which is not accessible for macroscopic electrochemical measurements. Phase engineering to improve the HER activity of MoS2 was investigated by Sun et al. [209] using high-resolution SECM (< 20 nm spatial resolution). The feedback mode of SECM, with ferrocenemethanol (Fc) as a mediator, was first employed to distinguish the 1T and 2H MoS2 regions (Figs. 7(a)–(c) ), and the SG/TC mode was used to measure HER activities across the same area of the substrate (Fig. 7(d)). The edges of 2H MoS2 are much more active than the interior, whereas the entire 1T MoS2 surface exhibits high HER activity. Combined with XPS, scanning transmission electron microscopy-electron energy loss spectroscopy (STEM-EELS), and scanning Kelvin probe microscopy (SKPM), the correlations between the MoS2 phase/structure and HER electrocatalytic performance were revealed, where the lower work function of the mixed-phase nanosheets contributed to more facile H2 generation. Like SECM, SECCM has been proven to be a powerful tool for revealing the structure and HER activity correlation on a variety of (nano)materials including polycrystalline metals [210,211], individual metal NPs [212], transitional metal dichalcogenides [124,213,214], iron nickel sulfides [215], hexagonal boron nitride [216], and chemically doped graphene [217]. Takahashi et al. used a high-resolution SECCM using a 20 nm diameter nanopipette with a hopping scanning mode to visualize the HER activity on 1H-MoS2 nanosheets and MoS2/WS2 heterostructures (Fig. 8(a) ) [213]. The heterogeneous HER activities at the edges and terrace regions of 1H-MoS2 are shown in Figs. 8(b)–(d). The edge regions revealed a lower overpotential than the terrace regions, but the Tafel slope remained the same. Figs. 8(e) and (f) showed different current values for the MoS2 and WS2 nanosheets, but no specific catalytic HER performance was obtained at the heterojunction. The electronic structure of 2D materials can be modified by the underlying metal support, which affects their electrocatalytic activities. The effect of metal supports (Au and Cu) on the HER electrocatalysis in hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) was studied by Unwin's group using SECCM [216]. Spatial-resolved voltammetry with a resolution of 500 nm and Tafel analysis revealed that electronic interactions between h-BN and the underlying metal substrate could tune the free energy of hydrogen-adsorbed atomic hydrogen (ΔG H*) and further modulate the HER electrocatalytic activity of h-BN. The Au-supported h-BN exhibited significantly enhanced HER-charge transfer kinetics, and the exchange current was two orders of magnitude larger than that of the Cu-supported h-BN. To fully elucidate the structural controls on electrocatalysis at metal interfaces, experiments should be performed to correlate the surface heterogeneity with the activity. The HER activity on nanoscale active sites, including crystallographic orientation, grain boundaries, and MnS inclusions of low carbon steel was studied by Unwin's group [211] using SECCM in combination with scanning electron microscopy (SEM), electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The HER activity shows a grain-dependent trend in the order of (100) > (111) > (101), whereas crystallographic defects such as grain boundaries have a more obvious influence on the HER than the crystal orientation (Figs. 9(a)–(e) ). Enhanced HER currents were also observed for the local MnS inclusions (Fig. 9(f)). SECCM has been proven to be sensitive to compositionally heterogeneous surfaces, as evidenced by a recent study of the local HER activity on the (111) crystal planes of iron nickel sulfides (Fe4.5Ni4.5S8) [215]. Significant HER activity differences were detected by SECCM, even with small variations in the surface Fe:Ni:S ratio. In conjunction with structural characterization, this observation suggests that Fe-enriched areas are less stable owing to the increasing corrosion process, which stems from sulfur release. This S-vacancy might promote the adsorption of H atoms, leading to a higher HER activity. Kumatani et al. [217] reported that the edge of doped holy graphene is significantly active toward HER, as evidenced by SECCM. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that N and P co-doping on the edges can lower the Gibbs free energy of the HER process. 3.1.2 Characterizing electrocatalytic processes Developments in operando EC-SPMs have enabled the investigation of electrocatalytic processes in an electrolyte solution with high resolution down to the atomic level. In this section, we mainly discuss the in-situ/operando investigation of the structure/morphology evolution and adsorption of reactants/intermediates during the HER process. EC-AFM is a powerful tool for monitoring the structure/morphological evolution of electrocatalysts under reaction conditions. The morphology change of CoS2 nanosheets drop-coated on highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) was studied by EC-AFM during HER electrocatalysis in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes [218]. The height, width, and area of CoS2 showed no obvious variation even after 2000 CVs cycles in an acidic medium, but changed significantly in an alkaline electrolyte, supporting its excellent HER electrocatalytic performance in acidic solutions. Combined with XPS characterization, the proportion of Co3+/Co2+ and the binding energy were investigated to explore the HER mechanism in acidic and alkaline electrolytes. The stability of HER electrocatalysts can also be explored using operando EC-SPMs. For example, Ahn et al. [219] used surface-interrogation SECM (SI-SECM) to study the stability of a CoP electrocatalyst, one of the most active transition metal phosphides for the HER, under mild operating conditions. The CoP film showed fast decomposition to oxidation (chemical oxidants and oxygen) equivalent to 0.4 V vs. NHE even under high flow rates of inert gas. The elemental ratio of cobalt to phosphorus remained constant during the degradation process. The proposed mechanism involves oxidation by dioxygen, followed by acid etching of the oxidized layer. This study shows that the surface chemistry of electrocatalysts can be investigated using the SI-SECM method during electrocatalytic reaction processes. The adsorption of reactants/intermediates can affect mass transfer and electron transfer kinetics, and characterization of the adsorption behavior is important for understanding the electrocatalysis mechanism [111]. For instance, Bard et al. [111] employed SI-SECM to directly measure adsorbed hydrogen (Hads) on a nickel surface to study the HER mechanism. As the nickel electrode is easily oxidized in an aqueous electrolyte, the “true” HER current overlaps with the reduction of the oxide. The substrate SG/TC mode was employed to analyze the hydrogen generated on the nickel. The coverage of Hads was determined by titration in SI-SECM experiments [179,220–222] reported by Bard's group. Based on the Tafel slope and analysis of the hydrogen surface coverage, hydrogen adsorption (Volmer step) is regarded as the rate-determining step (RDS) of the HER, and the surface oxide of the low-valence state promotes the Volmer step. 3.1.3 Visualizing single-particle electrochemistry Metal nanoparticle (NPs) systems have been used for electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution in real-life applications [223]. Monitoring electrocatalytic activity at the single NPs level has drawn significant attention because it provides a bottom-up approach to understanding electrocatalytic processes for complex metal NP systems. SECCM provides a novel approach to resolve the HER activity of individual NPs within an ensemble [126]. By examining the SECCM reactivity maps at various applied potentials, a wide dispersion of reactivities for single NPs was displayed, and a variance in reactivity was observed for NPs with similar sizes. These results emphasize the importance of morphology and local support in affecting the reactivity of single NPs other than their sizes, which has profound implications for practical catalyst design. Baker et al. [224] demonstrated the HER activity of individually engineered Au nanocubes (NCs) and Au nano-octahedra (ODs)) using SECCM. A statistical analysis based on nanoscale measurements revealed that Au NCs exhibit better HER catalytic performance than Au ODs. Moreover, particle-to-particle variations in HER activities were more obvious for Au NCs than for Au ODs. Nanometer-scale SECM was employed to determine the electrocatalytic activity of the single NPs [102]. Kim et al. [102] demonstrated the catalytic activity of individual Pt nanoparticles (NPs) (60–120 nm radius) deposited on a highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) surface in the HOR with SECM. Two stages of SECM experiments were performed. First, the topography image was obtained using an outer-sphere mediator, ferrocenyl methyl trimetylammonium cation (FcTMA+), at a constant tip-surface separation, as the mediator is not sensitive to different catalytic surfaces. Second, the HOR activity image over the same area was acquired based on inner-sphere H+ reduction/H2 oxidation, which could differentiate between the topography and active sites. Consequently, five individual Pt NPs were resolved in the SECM current maps. A large effective constant rate of ≥ 2 cm s−1 for HOR was determined for Pt NPs because of the enhanced mass transfer rate due to the formation of a nanoscale gap between the SECM tip and the PtNPs. 3.2 OER OER is the anodic reaction of water splitting such that 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− in acidic solution or 4OH− → 2H2O + O2 + 4e− in an alkaline electrolyte. Compared to the HER, the OER is a four-electron reaction that requires a higher energy barrier (higher overpotential) to overcome the HER, leading to sluggish kinetics. RuO2 is a representative OER electrocatalyst with high activity both in acidic and alkaline media [225,226]; however, it has low stability towards dissolution towards RuO4 [227,228]. IrO2, another state-of-the-art OER catalyst, exhibits good OER catalytic performance and is more stable than RuO2 [229]. However, it suffers from oxidation problems at high anodic potentials during the OER [230]. Both contain precious metals, which hinders their industrial application. Therefore, a variety of OER catalysts, including metal oxides [188,231], non-oxide materials such as metal chalcogenides [232,233], metal pnictides [234,235], and metal coordination complexes [236,237], have been comprehensively investigated. Understanding the OER mechanisms is the cornerstone for the rational design of catalysts with high activity and stability. Typically, the main descriptor governing the OER activity on metal oxides is the binding strength of oxygen on the catalysts following the Sabatier principle [238,239]. The scaling relations existing between the adsorption energies of oxygenated intermediate binding species have been found which provides a universal volcano shaped relationship that can be applied to a wide variety of oxide catalysts [239]. However, the mechanism mentioned has been challenged by recent experimental and theoretical findings [240,241]. Another oxygen lattice mechanism (LOM) has been proposed, which the lattice oxygen redox chemistry is involved [240–243]. This mechanism indicates that the active centers are not limited to the metal centers from the conventional mechanism; the lattice oxygen can be activated in the OER, which creates new possibilities for the development of new and more efficient OER catalysts. EC-SPMs provide breakthroughs for mechanism explanation by monitoring active sites, surface evolution, and intermediates in-situ/operando during OER [15,75,79,130]. 3.2.1 Surface reconstruction/dissolution Stability is highly desirable for the design of OER catalysts for practical applications. Surface reconstruction, dissolution, and redeposition can occur during OER processes owing to high anodic potentials, which may change the active sites and cause catalytic instability. Paoli et al. [19] evaluated the OER activity and corrosion behavior of mass-selected RuO2 NPs prepared by magnetron sputtering as a function of size using electrochemical measurements, electron microscopy, potentiodynamic STM, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The as-deposited catalysts show good mass activity of up to 0.6 A mg−1, which is one order of magnitude higher than that of state-of-the-art materials. EC-STM was used to directly visualize catalyst dissolution. The as-deposited Ru NPs were dissolved when the scan potential of EC-STM was raised from 1.3 to 1.5 V vs. RHE. However, the thermally oxidized nanoparticles RuO2 showed no corrosion in the same potential range, indicating that the stability of RuO2 is highly sensitive to surface treatment. Dynamic surface changes are essential to understand the stability of electrocatalytic materials. Stumm et al. [79] demonstrated the OER activity of cobalt oxide nanoislands (NIs) supported on Au(111) using EC-STM. In the anodic scan, the structure of both bilayer NIs (BL) and double-bilayer NIs (DL) on Au(111) were stable during OER, at potentials up to 1.5 VRHE above open circuit potential (0.8 VRHE). In the cathodic scan, BL became unstable at potentials of 0.5 VRHE. The mobile BL was formed and started to dissolve during the reduction of Co3+ to soluble Co2+ whereas DL retained its morphology to a much lower potential. The surface dynamics correlate with the dissolution process, aiding in understanding the stability of metal oxide catalysts. In-situ EC-AFM with high resolution and low invasion is another suitable tool for examining surface evolution under reaction conditions. It has been employed to demonstrate the interfacial evolution of Li2O2 on HOPG during the ORR/OER in Li-O2 batteries with the soluble catalyst 2,5-di-tert-butyl- 1,4-benzoquinone (DBBQ) in the electrolyte [22]. The ORR/ OER processes during discharge/charge were monitored in a dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-based electrolyte without/with the DBBQ catalyst. The different decomposition mechanisms of Li2O2 during OER were present: the toroid Li2O2 was formed at 2.46 V and decomposed at 3.82 V from the bottom to up without DBBQ; the flower-like Li2O2 grew at 2.70 V and started to decompose at 2.79 V with an outside-in approach at a higher rate in the presence of DBBQ. A Li strip was used as the reference electrode. Combined with the Gibbs free energy calculation analysis of all the related molecules in DMSO, the further catalytic mechanism of DBBQ was interpreted. Because DBBQ acts as an intermediary by promoting O2– transmission between Li2O2 and the electrode, the decomposition of Li2O2 during the OER in the presence of DBBQ took an outside-in approach, which is not hindered by the poor electrical conductivity of Li2O2. Another example of dynamic surface evolution was demonstrated on single-layer Ni(OH)2/NiOOH nanosheets using EC-AFM [244]. Reconstruction of Ni(OH)2 and insertion of ions were observed, which was accelerated at high potentials between 1 to 1.7 V vs. RHE associated with OER. Simultaneously, an increase in volume expansion and surface area was detected, and the redox capacity increased significantly by 300%. The incorporation of Fe cations into or onto the Ni(OH)2 nanosheets was heterogeneous as a function of the applied potential. When the concentration of Fe species is low, for example, 3 ppm Fe(NO3)3 in the electrolyte, the Fe cations preferentially integrate into the existing Ni (oxy)hydroxide, which significantly expands the volume. With the increasing addition of Fe ions up to 12 ppm Fe(NO3)3, Fe species were additionally deposited onto the place where little Ni (oxy)hydroxide existed, resulting in the formation of a second FeOOH phase. Similarly, Dette et al. [245] reported the dynamic morphological evolution of Ni1–δ Co δ O x H y nanosheets with different ratios of Ni to Co during electrochemical cycles using EC-AFM. It was found that a high Co content can form a structure with higher porosity, resulting in reduced mechanical stress and improved stability under electrochemical conditions. 3.2.2 Adsorption of reactants/intermediates Adsorption of reactants/intermediates on the catalytic active sites is a key step in electrocatalytic reactions, which can affect electron transfer and mass transfer during electrocatalytic processes. EC-STM has shown its advantage in characterizing the adsorption process because the interaction between the reactants and catalyst surface changes the contrast and contour of the adsorbed species, which is reflected in the EC-STM image. In-situ monitoring of the adsorption process of Co-based metalloporphyrins (5, 10, 15, 20 tetraphenyl-21H, 23H-porphyrin cobalt (II), CoTPP) at the molecular level under OER conditions was recently achieved by Wan et al. [75]. The CoTPP catalyst showed better OER activity with increasing electrolyte alkalinity in cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements. EC-STM measurements of CoTPP in acidic, alkaline, and neutral solutions were performed, as shown in Figs. 10(a)–(f) . In the acidic electrolyte, each CoTPP molecule can be distinguished as a bright dot (Figs. 10(a) and (b)) that corresponds to cobalt ions. However, CoTPP could be identified as a two-fold symmetry species containing two bright spots (Fig. 10(c)) in an alkaline solution. The coexistence of the two species was observed in a neutral solution (Fig. 10(d)). The morphological difference of CoTPP revealed that CoTPP-OH− species were inclined to form in a higher pH solution, which was further confirmed by the UV-vis adsorption spectra in Fig. 10(g). The CoTPP adsorption mechanism on Au(111) in an alkaline medium at different potentials was investigated in-situ using EC-STM (Figs. 10(h)–(k)), indicating that the transformation between the CoTPP-OH- species and CoTPP molecule was reversible. Compared with other EC-SPM characterization techniques, SI-SECM offers opportunities to quantitatively detect adsorbed intermediates and surface-active sites on a catalyst. Bard et al. [246] demonstrated two redox titrations with SI-SECM on electrodeposited Mn-based electrocatalysts, MnO x and CaMnO3, in a neutral solution. The potential-dependent reduction and oxidation states of Mn (MnIII, MnIV, and MnV) species were investigated. MnV species that induce OER were found in both structures. In the SI-SECM experiment, two reactions of MnV with a redox titrant (IrCl6 3–) and water occurred. The OER kinetics of the MnV species was studied by time-delayed titration at a substrate potential of 1.3 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The pseudo-first-order rate constant of MnV can be obtained by plotting ln[MnV] as a function of time delay. It was found that MnO x produced two types of active sites, where a “fast” and “slow” site showed a reaction rate constant of 1.21 and 0.24 s−1, respectively. In contrast, CaMnO3 exhibited only one fast kinetic behavior at a rate of 1.72 s−1. 3.2.3 Identification of structure-activity correlation In-situ SI-SECM can be used to quantitatively detect the transient reactivity of surface species in terms of the distribution of active sites. In Bard's study [179], the catalytic sites of the Ni1–x FexOOH electrode were identified by time-dependent titrations of SI-SECM. The OER kinetics of NiIV (slow site) and FeIV (fast site) were measured, where the “fast” site showed a rate constant of 1.7 s−1 per atom and its fraction matched the iron atom content in the material. Leonard et al. [110] prepared nanoamorphous (Ni, Fe) oxides synthesized using a microwave-assisted method for use as OER electrocatalysts. They utilized SI-SECM to explore the kinetics rates for OER and found that the amorphous structures only contain “fast” sites with a rate constant of 1.9 s−1, indicating amorphous materials have higher catalytic performance compared with the crystal-derived counterpart. Another study on the detection of active sites using SI-SECM was conducted on a CoPi catalyst surface. The CoIII and CoIV titrations and time-dependent measurements were separately performed. The reaction rate constants for CoIII and CoIV were determined to be 0.19 and > 2 s−1, respectively [247]. Coupled with other high-resolution microscopy techniques, in-situ EC-SPMs can be used to reveal structure-activity correlations in electrocatalysis. For example, the catalytic OER performance of a semi-2D nickel oxide nanosheet was examined using operando SECM with sub-20 nm resolution [29]. The ultrahigh resolution and sensitivity allowed us to image the higher activity of the edges from the basal plane surfaces, revealing that the current density of the edges was ~200 times higher than that at the fully coordinated surface. In combination with TEM (STEM) and ab initio calculations, the structure-activity correlation was successfully revealed for a structurally complex OER electrocatalyst. Schuhmann et al. [30] applied SECCM to examine the OER activity of single ZIF-derived C-N-doped C composite particles in an alkaline solution. A free-diffusing redox compound (osmium (II) complex) was used as an internal potential standard to compensate for the potential drift and to calculate the wetted area derived from each tip approaching. SECCM and SEM revealed that the increasing number of Co-N/C nanocomposite particles in the wetted area of the meniscus landing location contributed to the higher OER activity. The TOF derived from the different potentials (1.70, 1.75, 1.80 V vs. RHE) was 0.25 to 1.5 s−1 per Co atom, reflecting a higher intrinsic electrocatalytic activity with more positive anodic potentials. The TOF values decreased with an increase in the number of nanocomposite particles, indicating that increasing variations in the local chemical environment within the meniscus, such as the interfacial pH, local O2 supersaturation, and O2 gas bubbles, may influence the OER activity. Operando SECCM and EC-AFM coupled with correlative X-ray microscopy can establish a relationship between the OER activity, physicochemical properties, and electronic structure of single-crystalline β-Co(OH)2 particles [130]. SECCM in static voltage (1.87 vs. RHE)/continuous scanning mode demonstrated that a significantly enhanced current was observed at the edges of the particle compared with the basal plane (Fig. 11(a) ). The same result was obtained in hoping-mode SECCM, as shown in Fig. 11(b). Hydroxide ion (de)intercalation was monitored by EC-AFM in conjunction with an isothermal electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM). The height morphology maps (Fig. 11(c)) and line scan of particle height at different voltages (Fig. 11(d)) showed that the change in height reached a maximum at 1.39 V and the value decreased back to the initial state at approximately 1.58 V. Lateral expansion occurred with an increasing voltage for the translation of CoO x H y , and the particle contracted starting with the edges with a further higher voltage (Fig. 11(d)). The EQCM measurements (Fig. 11(e)) demonstrated a mass change with potential change, and a structural change in the CoO2 layers was proposed. During the oxidation process, the OH− ions are intercalated into β-Co(OH)2 to form an intermediate of α-CoO2H1.5·0.5H2O, and then the particle contracts to a stabilized β-CoOOH with a further increase in potential. Operando scanning transmission X-ray microscopy (STXM) was performed to determine the electronic structure during the OER process. STXM-X-ray absorbance microscopy (XAS) at the Co LIII-edge and Co oxidation state with changing potential challenged the traditional views of redox CoO x H y peaks for OER, revealing an average oxidation state of Co2.54+ at E 1 0’ instead of Co3+, and the average oxidation state of Co3+ at E 1 0’ instead of Co4+. The Tafel slope is plotted in Fig. 11(g) and is correlated with the local Co3+ coverage at the edges (Fig. 11(f)), which confirms that Co3+ is the active site. In the CoO x H y system, ion (de)intercalation processes with an applied voltage influence the surface OER activity by controlling the Co3+ active-site concentration at the edge. This operando study of layered oxide OER catalysts demonstrates how material properties can influence the catalytic activity and provides promising ways to improve the reactivity, such as tuning the thermodynamics of ion insertion and surface adsorption energy. 3.3 ORR As the cathode reaction of fuel cells, ORR is essential in clean energy conversion. In proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, hydrogen is oxidized (HOR) at the anode to produce protons that are transferred to the cathode and electrons that flow through an external circuit. Simultaneously, oxygen is reduced (ORR) by the electrons at the cathode. Alkaline anion exchange membrane (AEM) fuel cells have received increasing attention because of the rapid development of hydroxide anion conductive membranes. Without the requirement of an acidic environment similar to that of PEM fuel cells, various non-precious metal electrocatalysts that are not stable in low-pH environments can be used in AEM fuel cells. The ORR occurs via two pathways: the four-electron route, which reduces O2 to generate H2O and OH− in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively. The other mechanism is the two-electron reduction of O2 to H2O2 in an acidic solution or HO2 − in an alkaline medium. The ORR principle is complex not only because of multiple electronic transfers but also because of the influence [248], water polarity [249], and electrode dependence [250]. Some proposed mechanisms have been summarized in recent review papers [250–253]. However, the kinetics of the ORR is more sluggish than those of the HOR. An unaffordable amount of Pt loading (~0.4 mg cm−2) is required to achieve a satisfied fuel cell performance [254]. Therefore, enormous efforts have been devoted to the development of catalysts with low Pt contents and non-precious metal alternatives [251,255].
