EC-SPMs studies have concentrated on monitoring ORR processes and visualizing the distribution of active sites of ORR and have demonstrated increasing priority in the investigation of non-precious electrocatalysts. 3.3.1 In-situ monitoring electrocatalytic processes Metal-based phthalocyanine (MPc) molecular catalysts [256,257] have been regarded as promising nonprecious electrocatalysts towards the ORR because of their low cost and simple synthesis methods. The MPc molecule adsorbed on an Au(111) substrate [258,259] is an ideal system for EC-STM to investigate the ORR electrocatalytic process. Cyclic voltammetry and in-situ EC-STM were used to investigate the iron- phthalocyanine (FePc) role in the ORR [258]. The centered Fe ion in the adlayer revealed a high contrast in O2 saturated electrolyte, which refers to the FePc-O2 complex (E = 700 mV vs. saturated calomel electrode (SCE)), and it can be reversibly transformed to FePc adsorbate with low contrast under potential scanning (E scans from 350 to 50 mV vs. SCE). This study indicated that EC-STM can record the adsorption of O2 on FePc catalysts under ORR conditions. Electrocatalytic processes involving the adsorption of intermediate species have been studied by SI-SECM. Herein, Co-Fe bimetallic sub-nanocluster catalysts [260] were homogeneously decorated on carbon nanotubes derived from dual cross-linked polypyrrole (PPy) hydrogels. The synthesized CoFe-PPy exhibited excellent ORR and OER electrocatalytic performance, surpassing that of a commercial Pt/C (20%) catalyst. The operando SI-SECM technique was used to obtain the local thermodynamics and catalytic kinetics of CoFe-PPy. Compared to monometallic catalysts, the as-prepared bimetallic catalyst generated active intermediates at a lower overpotential (less than 200 mV). The underlying mechanism of the bimetallic catalyst has been revealed, not only showing faster kinetics to activate O2 but also providing a higher active site density. Stability is one of the most important parameters in the preparation of ORR catalysts. EC-AFM can monitor the surface changes involved in catalytic ORR processes. For example, the aging of Pt-Ni alloy catalyst films during accelerated durability tests was investigated using in-situ EC-AFM, ex-situ X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and synchrotron radiation photoelectron spectroscopy (SRPES) [261]. The as-deposited Pt-Ni films degraded severely under potential cycling (from 0 to 1.3 V vs. RHE), leading to almost complete destruction after 2000 cycles. However, the annealed films showed better stability owing to the redistribution of Pt and Ni atoms. 3.3.2 Identifying the distribution of the active sites The identification of active sites for the ORR using EC-SPMs remains an interesting topic for the design of rational electrocatalysts. For example, active site distribution on a Pt surface has been achieved using ECSTM [21]. It was found that both the terraces and steps of Pt(111) in an acidic electrolyte are ORR active, and the steps possess a higher current noise than the terraces. Bandarenka et al. [262] also applied this method to directly observe active centers at Pt(111) with steps in three types of alkaline electrolytes (LiOH, KOH, and CsOH) under reaction conditions. The most active sites for ORR were located on the terraces of Pt(111) for all alkaline electrolytes, while no ORR activity enhancement was observed on the steps. In contrast, the concave defects showed an obvious increase in ORR activity in the acidic medium. The SECCM technique has demonstrated its powerful ability to characterize the heterogeneity of the active sites. Schuhmann and co-workers [263] have reported a zoom-in method to visualize ORR activity of high-entropy alloys (HEA) catalyst, using SECCM with a range of single-barrel tips with diameters of 1.2 μm to 50 nm. The average ORR activity was observed with only a small statistical variation for larger tip sizes. By reducing the tip diameter, the statistical heterogeneity of the active sites can be revealed. In addition, high-resolution electrochemical measurements enabled by SECCM allowed the detection of local activity on the catalyst surface. The nanoscale electrocatalysis of ORR with a spatial resolution of 500 nm at pristine, kinked, and oxidized sites on individual carbon nanotubes has been explored by SECCM combined with other high-resolution techniques, including Raman and SEM [264]. The electrode construction is shown in Fig. 12(a) . From the cyclic voltammetry (CV) shown in Fig. 12(b), the current plateaus from –1.25 to 1.70 V vs. Ag/AgCl QRCE indicated a two-electron ORR pathway to form H2O2. Fig. 12(c) shows the representative SECCM map over a 10-μm length of a pristine SWNT at the onset potential of ORR, indicating that the ORR activity along the length direction is quite even. The kinked region of the SWNT showed an enhanced ORR current (Fig. 12(d)), and the line profile over the area (Fig. 12(e)) further confirmed this phenomenon. Electrochemical oxidation by CV was performed using SECCM to generate defects and oxygen-functionalized moieties. The ORR activity at the local place with oxidation revealed a 5-times increase compared to that at the same place without oxidation (Figs. 12(f) and (g)). Using SICM combined with Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM), Wang et al. [265] found a correlation between the surface charge and ORR catalytic activity of active sites on a defective carbon electrocatalyst. The defects (active sites) in highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) were controlled by plasma etching. The localized surface charge induced by the defects was demonstrated by SICM and KPFM. Electrochemical measurements and DFT calculations further revealed that the enhanced ORR activity was correlated with the increasing surface charge. 3.3.3 Probing single-particle electrocatalytic activity The single-particle system is a representative model for studying the electrocatalytic activity at the single-entity level. SECCM is a mobile droplet cell-based technique with high spatial resolution that enables thousands of electrochemical measurements to be performed across a surface. Simultaneously, the tip-to-substrate distance can be precisely controlled to simultaneously generate the topography. These characteristics make SECCM particularly attractive for probing the single-particle electrocatalytic activity. For example, the effect of the electrocatalytic process on the physicochemical properties of single NPs within an ensemble was investigated by Unwin et al. [266]. SECCM was used to study the ORR activity of size-selected Pt NPs (diameter ≈ 3 nm) deposited on a carbon-coated TEM grid at high mass transfer rates. At low nanoparticle (NP) surface coverage, the ORR activity decreased with successive electrochemical measurements owing to Pt NP surface poisoning caused by corrosion of the carbon support by peroxy-intermediates. This phenomenon was less prominent at a high surface coverage. Furthermore, the impact energy during Pt NPs deposition drastically affects the NP stability. STEM characterizations showed that the low-impact-energy Pt NPs possessed high mobility and were rearranged into groups because of uneven oxygen fluxes to the individual particles. The use of a TEM grid as a working electrode for the SECCM study enabled the correlation of local electrochemical activity with structural characterization by ex-situ TEM, which can be applied to a wide variety of electrocatalytic systems. 3.4 CO2RR The electrocatalytic CO2RR is a promising approach to mitigate carbon emissions and produce carbon-containing chemicals and fuels (CO, HCOOH, CH4, CH3OH, C2H5OH, etc.) [267,268]. The routes of CO2RR are highly complex and involve multiple electron and proton transfer steps, together with different possible intermediates and products. The entire CO2RR process can be generally divided into three steps [268]: (1) adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface to form *CO2 (or *CO2 −); (2) formation of various intermediates and products by stepwise transfer of electrons and/or protons, leading to various C1-C3 CO2RR products [269]; and (3) desorption of products. Note that the CO pathway can be regarded as a representative example of C1 product formation, while other similar pathways can be constructed, such as formic acid formation led by the *HCOO intermediate. For C2 production, the CO dimerization pathway has been proposed for Cu electrocatalysts in details [270–272], and several major and minor products have been produced, including glyoxal, acetate, glycolaldehyde, ethylene glycol, acetaldehyde, ethylene, and ethanol [273]. This wide variety of CO2RR products makes catalytic selectivity challenging for catalyst design. Furthermore, the HER is often treated as a side reaction for CO2RR because its reduction potential is close to that of some CO2RR half-reactions. However, commercial utilization of CO2 requires the development of highly efficient catalysts with good selectivity and low cost. To meet this requirement, operando EC-SPMs characterization under real working conditions is urgently needed [274–276]. The selectivity of the preferred products can be controlled by maximizing the exposure of certain crystalline facets and shape-selected nanostructures. In-situ EC-SPMs techniques, combined with other spectroscopic studies, can demonstrate how selectivity switches with structural evolution under potential changes [23]. During the CO2RR reaction process, the adsorbed reactants/intermediates can be further detected, showing obvious contrast changes characterized by in-situ EC-STM [81]. Moreover, the surface heterogeneity of CO2RR catalysts makes it difficult to correlate their structural properties with their reactivity. The local structural or electrochemical measurements enabled by EC-SPMs are powerful tools for overcoming these issues [123]. The advancements in EC-SPMs have highlighted the mechanism underlying CO2RR catalysts and are detailed in the following sections. 3.4.1 Monitoring structure reconstruction and structure-dependent activity Copper (Cu) has been regarded as a unique electrocatalyst to reduce CO2 into valuable fuels and chemicals [277,278], and the extent of hydrocarbon and alcohol production has been proven to be crystallographically orientation dependent [279]. Kim et al. [20] investigated the surface evolution of polycrystalline Cu surface in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH under a potential of -0.9 V vs SHE in the vicinity of CO2RR using operando EC-STM. The Cu surface underwent surface reconstruction, formed Cu(111) within 30 min, transformed to Cu(100) after another 30 min, and no further crystal orientation change occurred thereafter. These results explain why polycrystalline Cu electrodes exhibit Cu(100)-like behavior and primarily produce C2H4. This work offers a possible opportunity to use inexpensive polycrystalline Cu to generate products exclusive to expensive single-crystal Cu(100) electrodes. Similarly, potential-dependent surface reconstruction and morphology change of the Cu(100) surface during the CO2RR process were investigated using the EC-AFM method [24]. Nanoscale resolution EC-AFM has enabled the direct observation of surface transformation with potential sweeping from granular to smoothly curved surfaces (–0.5 VRHE) or structures with rectangular terraces (–1.0 VRHE) in a 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 electrolyte. Meanwhile, the increasing density of uncoordinated Cu sites has been identified with nanoscale imaging during the CO2RR with decreasing potential. Herein, the complex relationships among structure, defect density, and applied potential were revealed in-situ during CO2RR herein. The electrocatalytic CO2RR activity strongly depended on the structure of the catalysts. For example, Kanan and Unwin et al. explored the microstructural origin of locally enhanced CO2RR at and around grain boundaries (GBs) on polycrystalline gold electrodes has been explored by Kanan and Unwin et al. [123] using high-resolution SECCM (tip diameter ≈ 200 nm) and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD). First, a set of SECCM scans was performed on sample A to map H2 evolution under Ar. The EBSD characterization in Fig. 13(a) shows that the scanned region contains one low-angle grain boundary (GB1) and a high-angle GB (GB2). Current density SECCM map at –1.05 V vs. Ag/AgCl and its histogram distribution, and corresponding SEM image reveal that H2 evolution on Au electrode is not structure defect dependent (Figs. 13(b)–(d)). In contrast, CO2RR showed microstructural sensitivity, as shown in Figs. 13(e)–(h). CO2RR activity is grain-dependent, and the most active sites are located at the slip band (SB). Furthermore, combined with high-resolution EBSD, no correlation between the lattice strain and electrochemical activity was observed, but a large geometrically necessary dislocation (GND) density in the SB region, which may contribute to a higher coverage of highly active undercoordinated sites. Sample B, with more bulk defects, was scanned using SECCM (Figs. 13(i) and (j)). The measurements herein demonstrated that CO2RR on Au is dependent on surface-terminating dislocations, which are usually located at the GBs and slip bands. However, H2 evolution was not dependent on the microstructural uncoordinated sites. 3.4.2 Characterizing adsorption of reactants/intermediates Operando EC-STM and polarization-modulation infrared spectroscopy (PMIRS) were used to study the adsorption of CO on Cu(100) in alkaline solution at CO2RR potentials [81]. Some conclusions have been addressed: (1) the surface coordination of CO on Cu(111) is weak; (2) CO adsorption only occurs when the potential is more negative than –0.8 V vs. SHE; (3) two types of adlattices are formed with Cu(100)-c(2 × 2)-CO or Cu(100)-()R45°-CO; (4) the surface coverage of adsorbed CO is 0.5; and (5) CO molecular orientation at the atop sites is vertical. In addition, in-situ EC-STM has been applied to study a class of important molecular catalysts, metal phthalocyanines, and catalyzed CO2RR [280]. An ordered adlayer of cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) was prepared on an Au(111) substrate. In CO2 saturated electrolyte, the proportion of high-contrast absorbed species (CoPc-CO2) was found to be larger than that in Ar and air environments using EC-STM. The CoPc-CO2 formation was further confirmed by theoretical simulations. The transformation between high-contrast CoPc-CO2 (–0.8 V vs. SCE) and low-contrast CoPc (–1.25 V vs. SCE) was studied using operando EC-STM at different potentials. In the potential step experiments, dynamic information of CO2RR's initial stage was obtained, including the reduction of CoPc and the CO2 binding steps. The rate limiting step was determined to be the latter by calculating the rate constants, with a value of (7.9 ± 0.15) × 1010 molecules cm−2 s−1. The calculated rate constant for the reduction of CoPc was on the order of 3.0 × 1017 molecules cm−2 s−1, which is much larger than that of CO2 binding. A deeper understanding of metal phthalocyanine-catalyzed CO2RR was achieved by EC-STM. 3.4.3 Investigating reaction pathways and selectivity The integration of advanced operando experiments and simulations is powerful for exploring the preferred reaction pathways for the CO2RR. For example, the CO2RR mechanism into selectivity of C2 products over Cu catalysts has been theoretically and experimentally examined [281]. The grand canonical potential kinetics (GCP-K) methodology predicted that the rate of C2 production over Cu without O is ~500 times slower than H2 production. In contrast, the rate of C2 production with model Cu2O is > 5000 times faster than that of pure Cu, which is comparable to H2 production. Time-dependent detection of polycrystalline Cu and thick Cu2O using gas chromatography and high-performance liquid chromatography was employed to validate the calculation results, indicating that subsurface O during CO2RR can enhance the C–C coupling reaction. In-situ EC-AFM at –0.8 VRHE over Cu and thick Cu2O under CO2RR conditions ruled out the possibility that topology or roughness are the main factors affecting the selectivity of C2 products. Combined with other correlative characterizations such as XPS and Raman spectroscopy, the disordered Cu0, which involves the oxygen content within the catalyst, is critical in long-term C2 production. The multicarbon product selectivity of shape-selected nanocatalysts was studied by Cuenya et al. [23] as CO2RR is highly sensitive to the surface structure. The effects of different factors, including structure, chemical state, and defects, on the catalytic selectivity of Cu nanocubes during CO2RR were revealed using operando EC-AFM, X-ray adsorption fine-structure spectroscopy (XAFS), and XPS [23]. Under a potential of –1.1 V vs. RHE, the Cu nanocubes supported on carbon showed dynamic morphological changes with surface roughening, loss of (100) facets, and formation of pores. The chemical status was altered by the loss of Cu and the reduction of the Cu x O species. The selectivity for CO2RR versus HER decreased with decreasing cube size because of more obvious structural changes. A CO2RR study of Cu cubes supported on Cu foils was conducted for comparison with Cu cubes on a carbon substrate. In contrast, enhanced morphological stability and a higher C2/C1 product ratio were observed. These results indicate that not only nanostructure engineering of catalysts is important for CO2RR, but also its interaction with the underlying support for stabilizing Cu+ species on Cu nanocubes. Leonard et al. [112] reported the utilization of Substrate Generation-Tip Collection Scanning Electrochemical Microscopy (SG-TC SECM) for in-situ detection of selective CO2RR on a reduced In2O3 surface. The In0-In2O3 composite was synthesized by electrochemically reducing In2O3 in-situ in an Ar-saturated electrolyte before being exposed to CO2. The selectivity of In0-In2O3 was changed to reduce CO2 to CO with near 100% selectivity at a low overpotential (–1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl) instead of formate. SG-TC SECM measurements showed that the first reduction step of CO2 on In0-In2O3 was reversible. However, it was irreversible on the In foil, indicating that the mechanism of CO2RR may have changed. 4 Conclusions and perspectives In this review, we summarize the recent progress of in-situ electrochemical scanning probe microscopy (EC-SPMs) in the research of HER/HOR, OER, ORR, and CO2RR. In-situ EC-SPMs are powerful techniques for studying the structure-activity relationships, adsorption of reactants/intermediates, structure evolution, stability and preferred pathways, and selectivity under reaction conditions with nanoscale resolution. EC-STM can achieve ultrahigh resolution (at the atomic level) to solve key issues in electrocatalysis. It is suitable to observe the distribution of active sites and monitor the reaction intermediates of electrocatalysts, which are crucial for explaining the mechanism. Thus far, progress has been made for precious metals such as Pt, Pd, and Ru [19,21,262]. 2D layered materials [205] and chemically modified MPc [256,257,280]. EC-AFM shares various similarities with EC-STM and, more importantly, it can be applied to semiconductors or soft materials on electrodes. EC-AFM can achieve a larger scanning area than EC-STM can. Therefore, it is easier to investigate surface reconstruction [22] or degradation [23] during electrocatalytic processes. SECM and SECCM have highlighted local electrocatalytic activities [125], particularly making them suitable for studying commercially used nanoparticle (NP) catalysts on supports. In addition, the electron transfer kinetics information [26,246] of the catalysts can be more easily obtained by SECM and SECCM, although their spatial resolutions are not comparable to those of EC-STM and EC-AFM. Operando EC-SPMs have significantly contributed to the understanding of the electrocatalytic mechanism and the design of rational electrocatalysts. However, several challenges remain to be addressed. First, the construction of a proper catalytic model system similar to a practical application scenario is vital in an in-situ electrocatalysis study using EC-SPM. The NPs system is often used in industrial applications, and its model system for presenting actual catalysts is relatively easy to construct for operando EC-SPMs investigations. The complex catalyst system can be broken down into a set of well-defined structures and other features to connect with local electrocatalytic activities. Recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have exhibited improved electrocatalytic performance owing to their ultrahigh atom utilization and unique electronic and geometric properties [282,283]. Single-atom alloys (SAAs) are a new class of single-site catalysts that comprise a small amount of one catalytically active metal dispersed into the surface of a more inert metal host and are characterized by high selectivity with resistance to deactivation and follow spillover pathways leading to bifunctional mechanism. Atomic-resolution STM has allowed the direct observation of the structural evolution of SAAs in response to reaction mixtures [284,285]. However, it is still challenging to manipulate in-situ EC-STM in an electrochemical environment for characterizing SAAs during electrocatalytic reactions because the imaging resolution may decrease owing to the diffusion of products. Additionally, amorphous materials have demonstrated superior electrocatalytic performance over their crystalline counterparts owing to their abundant defects and coordination unsaturated sites [286]. More powerful in-situ EC-SPMs characterization is urgently required to provide a complete understanding of the mechanism by visualizing the phase transition, structural properties, and active sites of amorphous materials under real reactions. Second, within the EC-SPMs field, hybrid techniques with dual probes, SECM-AFM, SECM-STM, SECM-SICM, and SECM-SECCM, can provide both local structure and electrochemical information during electrocatalytic reactions, which is crucial for revealing the heterogeneous electrocatalytic activities. These techniques create the possibility of investigating a single entity at the nanoscale, which is described in detail in Section 2.5. However, the analysis of the huge amount of data generated by these hybrid techniques and theoretical considerations for predicting the current response is challenging for researchers. Third, operando X-ray microscopy and in-situ STEM in liquid/gas phases can offer dynamic chemical and structural information on working electrocatalysts at the electrode-electrolyte interface [287]. Using a suite of correlative EC-SPMs and these techniques will establish a link between the electrochemical activity, local physicochemical properties, and electronic structure of electrocatalysts, which can achieve an in-depth understanding of the electrocatalytic mechanism and aid in the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts. Finally, the formation of nanobubbles should be considered when EC-SPMs are employed to study gas-involved electrocatalytic reactions, particularly for the HER and OER. The nanobubbles remaining on the catalyst surface reduce the electrolyte flow to the active sites, increase the reaction overpotential, and result in decreased catalytic activity. The applied potential must be precisely tuned to avoid this phenomenon. EC-AFM [288,289] and SECCM [290,291], have proven to be powerful tools for monitoring such processes at the nanoscale and investigating the factors influencing bubble formation. References 1 Z.W. Wenping Sun is a professor at School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University. He received his B.S. degree in 2008 and Ph.D. degree in 2013 in Materials Science from the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC). His research expertise includes electrocatalysis, fuel cells, and batteries, especially the design of novel materials and structures, and fundamental understandings of related electrochemical processes.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis is critical in improving the energy conversion efficiency, decreasing carbon emissions, and promoting the development of the green energy industry. A deep understanding of the electrocatalytic processes at nanostructured electrochemical interfaces (electrodes) is required to elucidate the electrocatalytic mechanism and facilitate the rational design of electrocatalysts. Electrocatalytic surfaces, which are structurally and compositionally heterogeneous, are usually analyzed using classical macroscopic electrochemical methods that lack the high spatial resolution and temporal sensitivity required for localized electrochemical measurements. In this regard, advances in electrochemical scanning probe microscopy, including electrochemical scanning tunneling, electrochemical atomic force, scanning electrochemical, and scanning electrochemical cell microscopies, offer significant opportunities to study electrocatalytic phenomena at nanometer and ultimately atomic scales during the reaction process. In this review, we first introduce the basic principles, features, and advantages and disadvantages of each technique of these scanning probe microscopies and outline the key advancements of each technique, particularly in investigating electrocatalysis. Subsequently, hybrid techniques of probe microscopy with synergistic effects are introduced. Then, we summarize the recent progress in the application of in-situ characterization methods in electrocatalysis, including hydrogen evolution/oxidation, oxygen evolution, and CO2 reduction reactions, focusing on the structure-activity correlation, structure evolution/stability, adsorption of the reactants or intermediates, preferred reaction pathways, and selectivity. Finally, the challenges and future developments of in-situ scanning probe microscopy in electrocatalysis are discussed.
